Getting Started with TidyDensity

Source: vignettes/getting-started.Rmd
getting-started.Rmd
library(TidyDensity)

Example

This is a basic example which shows you how easy it is to generate data with TidyDensity:

library(TidyDensity)
library(dplyr)
library(ggplot2)

tidy_normal()
#> # A tibble: 50 × 7
#>    sim_number     x      y    dx       dy     p       q
#>    <fct>      <int>  <dbl> <dbl>    <dbl> <dbl>   <dbl>
#>  1 1              1 -0.488 -3.05 0.000504 0.5   -0.216 
#>  2 1              2  0.105 -2.94 0.00128  0.508  0.212 
#>  3 1              3  0.257 -2.82 0.00296  0.516  0.325 
#>  4 1              4  0.597 -2.70 0.00622  0.524  0.597 
#>  5 1              5 -0.322 -2.59 0.0119   0.533 -0.0962
#>  6 1              6 -1.90  -2.47 0.0209   0.541 -2.26  
#>  7 1              7  0.576 -2.35 0.0334   0.549  0.579 
#>  8 1              8 -1.01  -2.23 0.0489   0.557 -0.624 
#>  9 1              9  0.168 -2.12 0.0658   0.565  0.258 
#> 10 1             10  1.00  -2.00 0.0822   0.573  0.995 
#> # … with 40 more rows

An example plot of the tidy_normal data.

tn <- tidy_normal(.n = 100, .num_sims = 6)

tidy_autoplot(tn, .plot_type = "density")

tidy_autoplot(tn, .plot_type = "quantile")

tidy_autoplot(tn, .plot_type = "probability")

tidy_autoplot(tn, .plot_type = "qq")

We can also take a look at the plots when the number of simulations is greater than nine. This will automatically turn off the legend as it will become too noisy.

tn <- tidy_normal(.n = 100, .num_sims = 20)

tidy_autoplot(tn, .plot_type = "density")

tidy_autoplot(tn, .plot_type = "quantile")

tidy_autoplot(tn, .plot_type = "probability")

tidy_autoplot(tn, .plot_type = "qq")
